content_text: Standard Oil (Indiana) founded as subsidiary of Standard Oil Trust.
Standard Oil of Indiana founded with dissolution of Standard Oil.
Standard Oil of Indiana purchases Pan American Petroleum.
Standard Oil of Indiana licenses "thermal cracking" process for producing gasoline to competing oil companies.
Standard Oil of Indiana acquires controlling interest in Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company.
Standard Oil (Indiana) founded as subsidiary of Standard Oil Trust.
Standard Oil of Indiana founded with dissolution of Standard Oil.
Standard Oil of Indiana purchases Pan American Petroleum.
Standard Oil of Indiana licenses "thermal cracking" process for producing gasoline to competing oil companies.
Standard Oil of Indiana acquires controlling interest in Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company.
Standard Oil of Indiana sells Venezuela operation to Jersey.
Pan American and Standard of Indiana merge, new company is called American Oil Company.
Amoco begins joint venture with Iran independent of Iranian Oil Consortium.
Amoco signs agreement with Shah of Iran.
Amoco Egypt Oil Company, Cairo, founded.
Amoco Sharjah Oil Company, Sharjah, U.A.E., in partnership with UEA, produces natural gas and natural gas liquids in Sharjah.
Amoco Oman Oil Company begins oil and gas exploration program.
Atlantic Petroleum Storage Company founded.
Atlantic Petroleum Storage Company establishes Atlantic Refining Company (Atlantic).
Atlantic sold to John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Trust.
Richfield Oil Corporation founded.
Standard Oil Trust dissolved under Sherman Antitrust Act, and Atlantic is spun off as independent company.
Sinclair Oil Corporation, founded by Harry F. Sinclair.
Richfield goes into receivership and Sinclair merges with Rio Grande Oil and Prairie Pipeline and Prairie Oil and Gas Companies.
Richfield Oil Corporation emerges from receivership.
Atlantic begins offshore Gulf Coast production.
Atlantic purchased the Hondo Oil & Gas Company.
Richfield Oil Corporation merges with Atlantic Refining Company, creating Atlantic Richfield Company.
ARCO partners with Exxon for Alaskan North Slope production.
ARCO acquires Sinclair Oil Corporation.
ARCO headquarters moves from New York City to Los Angeles.
ARCO acquires the Anaconda Company.
ARCO divests East Coast marketing and refining operations.
Tricentrol acquired by ARCO.
ARCO completes merger with Houston based Union Texas Petroleum Holding Inc.
ARCO forms anew publicly held company, Lyondell Petrochemical.
ARCO's U.S. oil and gas business restructured and divided into four business units ARCO Permian, ARCO Western Energy, ARCO Long Beach.
Vastar Resources Inc. initiates a public offering of 17 million shares of its common stock.
ARCO signs Production Sharing Contract with Sonatrach, the Algerian state oil company, to undertake major Enhanced Oil Recovery project in.
ARCO and Russia's largest oil company, LUKOIL, sign joint venture agreement to invest in oil and gas projects in Russia and other countries.

ARCO subsidiary (Western Midway Co.) and a unit of Mobil Corporation reaches agreement to exchange oil and gas properties in California's San Joaquin Valley and the Gulf of Mexico; The California properties owned by Western Midway go to Mobil, while Mobil oil and gas properties in the Gulf go to Western Midway.
ARCO sells majority interest in ARCO Chemical Company and divests its coal assets in the U.S.
Ashland Refining Company of Ashland, Ky., founded as a refining arm of Swiss Oil Company of Lexington.
Ashland Purchases Tri-State Refining.
Acquires Cumberland Pipeline Company's eastern Kentucky pipeline network.
Ashland Refining merges with Swiss Oil to form Ashland Oil & Refining Company.
Ashland Oil & Refining Company products first sold under the brand name "Ashland".
Ashland and Allied Oil merge.
Ashland and Aetna Oil merge, Ashland acquires Kentucky retail marketing operation Freedom-Valvoline, including Valvoline Motor Oil brand and also acquires Southern Pipe Line Company.
Frontier Oil Refining of Buffalo, N.Y., and National Refining of Cleveland, Ohio, join Ashland.
Acquisition of R. J. Brown Company of St. Louis.
Ashland acquires United Oil.
Ashland acquires Warren Brothers construction company.
Ashland purchases ADM Chemical Group and forms Ashland.
Ashland forms Ashland Petroleum operating division and Arch Mineral.
Ashland changes name to Ashland Oil, Inc.
Ashland acquires Northwestern Refining of St. Paul, Minn. and the SuperAmerica retail marketing chain.
Exploration and production activities are consolidated into Ashland Exploration.
Construction division is formed, and Ashland Coal is created.
Ashland acquires The Permian Corporation and merges with Scurlock Oil Company.
Ashland Chemical acquires most of Unocal's chemical distribution business, establishing the IC&S Division.
Ashland's Valvoline acquires Zerex.
Ashland changes company's name to Ashland Inc.
Ashland signs agreements with Marathon to combine the refining, marketing and transportation assets of the companies.
Pacific Coast Oil Company established.
Pacific Coast Oil purchased by Standard Oil, but remains separate operation.
Pacific Coast Oil consolidated with other Western US operations of Standard Oil into Standard Oil Company (California).
Dissolution of Standard Oil Trust makes Standard Oil of California (Socal) independent.
Socal merges with Pacific Oil Company.
Socal establishes Bahrain Petroleum Company to hold Bahrain concession.
Bahrain Petroleum strikes oil in Bahrain.
Socal wins Saudi Arabia concession; Socal establishes California-Arabia Standard Oil Company, Casoc, to hold concession for Saudi Arabia.
Socal discoveries oil in Saudi Arabia.
Texaco joins with Standard Oil of California (later Chevron), to found the Arab-American Oil Company.
Texaco purchases half interest in Bahrain Petroleum and California-Arabian Standard Oil Company (Calarabian) from Socal.
California-Texas company, Caltex, founded as a joint venture between Socal and Texaco as outlet for future oil production in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia.

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Socal buys Standard of Kentucky.
Bahraini government acquires 60% interest in BAPCO.
Bahraini government acquires remaining interest in BAPCO.
Socal buys Gulf Corporation and after restructuring changes name to Chevron Corporation.
Chevron undertakes a joint venture with the government of the Republic of Kazakhstan forming a new company named Tengizchevroil.
Pennzoil Company assimilates Chevron.
Continental Oil and Transportation Company founded.
Continental Oil and Transportation Company reincorporated as Continental within the Standard Oil trust.
Continental Oil reincorporated after breakup of Standard Oil Trust.
Marland Oil Company founded.
Continental Oil company merged with portions of Rocky Mountain (a former component of Standard oil) and Marland.
Conoco becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of by E.I.
Conoco reorganized as Continental Group.
Standard Oil of New Jersey formed by Standard Oil Trust.
Standard Oil of New Jersey establishes Anglo-American Oil Co. (predecessor of Esso Petroleum Co.) to market oil in the British Isles.
Standard Oil of New Jersey becomes a holding company for Standard Oil Interests, a subsidiary of Standard Oil.
Standard Oil of New Jersey gains control of Imperial Oil Limited of Canada.
Standard Oil of New Jersey acquires interest in Turkish (now Iraq) Petroleum Co.
Standard Oil of New Jersey  becomes independent with dissolution of Standard Oil Trust.
Humble Oil Company formed.
Jersey acquires majority ownership of Humble Oil.
Anglo-American acquired by Jersey.
Socony-Vacuum and Standard of New Jersey merge their Far East facilities and interests into a 50-50 venture called Standard-Vacuum Oil.
Jersey affiliate, Imperial, strikes oil in Canada.
Anglo-Iranian, Jersey and Socony sign 20-year contract with Iran.
Jersey (30%) and Socony-Vacuum (10%) join Socal (30%) and Texaco (30%) in Aramco venture.
Jersey buys remainder of Humble Oil.
Jersey strikes oil in Libya.
Jersey begins to market gasoline under the brand name Esso.
Jersey purchases Monterey Oil.
Jersey buys Honolulu Oil.
Assets of Stanvac split between Jersey and Socony Mobil.
Jersey changes name to Exxon.
Iraq nationalizes Iraq Petroleum Company, of which Exxon is 12% owner.
Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi, Kuwait and Qatar acquire 25% interest in Exxon's production operations (in country), with right to increase stake.
Exxon buys Colony Oil Shale Project.
Exxon sells Esso Standard Libya to Libyan government.
Exxon ends Colony Oil Shale Project.
Exxon acquires 48% of Hunt Oil Company's production sharing agreement in North Yemen.
Exxon and Mobil announce plans for merger.
Pacific Western Oil Corporation incorporated as a holding company for Edward L. Doherty and family which subsequently came under the control of J. Paul Getty.
1930s: Rocky Mountain division of Pacific Western, a Getty subsidiary, begins oil exploration in Saudi Arabia.
Pacific Western wins Saudi Arabia concession.
Getty's Western Pacific Oil Corporation signs concession for Saudi half of the Neutral Zone with Saudi government.
All of J. Paul Getty's oil holdings organized under Getty Oil.
Getty acquires Tidewater Oil.
Texaco acquires Getty.
Guffey Oil founded.
Gulf Refining Company founded.
William Mellon reorganizes Guffey Oil and Gulf Refining under name of Gulf Oil Corporation.
Gulf Oil Corporation forms Eastern Gulf Oil Company.
Gulf joins Turkish Petroleum Company.
Gulf buys Paragon Refining Company.
Gulf sells its share of Iraq Petroleum Company to Socal.

Anglo-Iranian and Gulf Oil Corporation establish Kuwait Oil Company as a 50-50 joint venture to compete for Kuwait concession (which they obtain); Subsequent agreement establishes British control of KOC.
Acquires Warren Petroleum.
Gulf purchases 10% in Syncrude Canada Limited.
Chevron buys Gulf.
Ohio Oil Company founded.
Ohio Oil Company purchased by J.D.
Marathon headquarters moved to Findlay, Ohio.
Standard Oil Company of Ohio  separated from Rockefeller's "Standard Trust".
Ohio Oil Company renamed the Marathon Oil Company.
Marathon buys Plymouth Oil.
Marathon becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of United States Steel Corporation, which has since become USX Corporation.
USX issues separate shares of common stock to reflect the performance of its two major businesses (steel and oil) and reinstates Marathon's symbol (MRO) on major stock exchanges.
Marathon Oil Company headquarters moved to Houston.

Ashland signs agreements with Marathon to combine the refining, marketing and transportation assets of the companies; Marathon Ashland Petroleum LLC formed Ashland acquires 38 percent of Marathon Ashland Petroleum LLC.
After resigning as a geologist with Phillips Petroleum Co., T. Boone Pickens forms development and production company called Petroleum Exploration.
Altair Oil and Gas is established to conduct oil and gas exploration in Canada.
Petroleum Exploration, Inc., and Altair merge to form Mesa Petroleum Co
Mesa Petroleum Co. shares began trading on the American Stock Exchange.
In hostile takeover, Pickens merges larger Hugoton into Mesa.
Mesa sells holdings in Canada and the North Sea to reduce debt and buy additional Hugoton reserves; Mesa also creates the Mesa Royalty.
Mesa forms Gulf Investors Group (GIG).
Mesa repurchases nearly 90 percent of the GIG units in a $500 million public tender offer.
The Mesa Petroleum Company changes its name to the Mesa Limited Partnership.
Mesa purchases Pioneer Corporation.
MESA partnership acquires gas reserves from Tenneco Inc.
Mesa Limited Partnership changes name to MESA Inc.
The Vacuum Oil Co. incorporated.
Standard Oil Co., headed by John D. Rockefeller, purchases a three-quarter interest in Vacuum.
Rockefeller and four partners organize Standard Oil Company in Ohio.
Rockefeller organizes his various oil holdings into the Standard Oil Trust, with headquarters in New York.
Standard Oil of New York formed.
Standard Oil Company of New York (Socony) founded with dissolution of Standard Oil.
Socony purchases a 45% interest in Magnolia Petroleum Co.
Socony purchases the properties of General Petroleum Corp. of California.
Vacuum acquires the Lubrite Refining Co., a refining and marketing company based in St. Louis.
Socony acquires White Eagle Oil & Refining Co.
Vacuum acquires Wadhams Oil Corp., and the White Star Refining Co.
Socony acquires all the assets of Vacuum Oil Co. and changes its name to Socony-Vacuum Corp.
Socony-Vacuum and Standard of New Jersey merge their Far East facilities and interests into a 50-50 venture called Standard-Vacuum Oil.
Socony-Vacuum Corp. changes its name to Socony-Vacuum Oil Co., Inc.
Anglo-Iranian, Jersey and Socony sign 20-year contract with Iran.
Jersey (30%) and Socony-Vacuum (10%) join Socal (30%) and Texaco (30%) in Aramco venture.
Socony-Vacuum changes name to Socony Mobil Oil Company.

Magnolia Petroleum and General Petroleum merged with other domestic subsidiaries into Socony Mobil Oil Company; Two major operating divisions created within the company: Mobil Oil Co. for the U.S. and Canada, and Mobil International Oil Co. for the rest of the world (except the areas in which Stanvac had interests).
Mobil Chemical Co. formed.
Mobil Petroleum Co. Inc. formed to oversee Socony Mobil's 50% interest in Stanvac.
Assets of Stanvac split between Jersey and Socony Mobil.
Socony Mobil Oil Co. changes name to Mobil Oil Corporation.
Mobil enters joint venture with Iranian Oil Company.
Mobil's 11.875% stake in Iraq Petroleum Company is nationalized.
Mobil increases its share of Aramco from 10% to 15%  Mobil completes acquisition of Marcor, the holding company for Montgomery Ward Department Stores.
Mobil completes acquisition of Marcor, the holding company for Montgomery Ward Department Stores.
Mobil Corporation formed as holding company.
Mobil sells 51% of its Turkish refinery to Turkish Petroleum.
Mobil acquires 100% of Superior Oil.

Yanbu Petrochemical Company (YANPET), a joint venture petrochemicals complex at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia plant begins operation; Mobil and Saudi Basic Industries Corporation (SABIC) are 50-50 partners in YANPET.
The Qatargas project, in which Mobil has a 10% interest, comes on line producing first LNG from Qatar.
Mobil commissions two new plants in Yemen and Syria.
Second Qatargas liquefaction train completed.
Exxon and Mobil announce plans for merger.
Cities Service Company formed.
Occidental Petroleum founded.
Cities Service Company obtains Dhofar province concession in Oman.
Armand Hammer buys Occidental Petroleum.
Cities Service Company begins marketing products under the brand name "CITGO".
Occidental wins oil concession in Libya.
Occidental acquires Cities Service Company.
Occidental reorganized Cities' assets and sells newly formed "CITGO Petroleum Corporation" to Southland Corporation
1980s: Libya nationalizes 51% of Occidental's operation in Libya.
Occidental acquired the Midcon Corporation.
Occidental Petroleum Corp. completes acquisition of Placid Oil Co., which was founded in 1936 by H.L.
Occidental purchases 19% stake in Clark USA.
Occidental and Royal Dutch/Shell, Anglo-Dutch oil group complete a $1bn global asset swap.
Occidental sells Occidental Netherlands Inc. unit to TransCanada Pipelines Ltd.
Occidental sells Occidental Netherlands Inc. unit to TransCanada Pipelines Ltd.  South Penn Oil Company organized as a unit of Standard Oil Company.
Name "Pennzoil" trademarked by Pennsylvania Refining Company, a predecessor to Pennzoil.
Bill Liedtke, John Overby, and George Bush form Zapata Offshore Oil Company.
Pennzoil Company is formed through consolidation of South Penn Oil Company, STETCO Petroleum Corporation and Zapata Offshore Oil Company.
Pennzoil Company acquires United Gas Corporation.
Pennzoil Company assimilates Chevron.
Pennzoil Company signs oil development deal with Qatar.
Pennzoil Company agrees to concession agreement with Egypt for Gulf of Suez.
Pennzoil-Quaker State Company was formed with merger of Pennzoil and Quaker State.

Simultaneous with the Pennzoil-Quaker State merger, the Pennzoil Company's marketing, manufacturing and fast oil change businesses (Pennzoil Products Group) is spun off and renamed the PennzEnergy Company.
Phillips brothers begin oil exploration.
Phillips Petroleum Company founded by Frank Phillips.
Phillips forms the predecessor to what today is GPM Gas Corp.
Phillips Research and Development Group formed.
Phillips' Kenai LNG Plant begins operation.
Phillips successfully fends off hostile take-over attempts.
GPM Gas Corporation formed.
Marcus Samuel starts import export business in London.
Royal Dutch Company launched.
Marcus commissions the first special oil tanker and delivers 4,000 tons of Russian kerosene to Singapore and Bangkok.
Samuel's company begins to operate under the name Shell Transport and Trading Company, Limited.
Shell and Dutch company N.V. Koninklijke Nederlandsche Maatschappij tot Explotatie van Petroleum-bronnen in Nederlandsch-Indie form the Asiatic Petroleum Company.
Royal Dutch and Shell group begins joint marketing campaign under name "British Dutch".

1906-British Dutch Group acquires producing interests in: Romania (1906), Russia (1910), Egypt (1911), Venezuela (1913) and Trinidad (1914)  Royal Dutch/Shell partnership is extended worldwide, with the creation of the Royal Dutch / Shell Group of Companies.
Royal Dutch/Shell partnership is extended worldwide, with the creation of the Royal Dutch / Shell Group of Companies.
Trading in the US starts after the acquisition of the American Gasoline Company, an American marketing company.
Turkish Petroleum Company founded with 50% ownership by Turkish National Bank, 25% Deutsche Bank, 25% Royal Dutch/Shell.
Formation of the Shell Company in California.
Royal Dutch/Shell buys Mexican Eagle.
Shell Union Oil Corporation  formed to consolidate Shell interests in the US with those of the Union Oil Company of Delaware.
Shell, Total, and Partex form the consortium Petroleum Development (Oman and Dhofar) later, Petroleum Development Oman.
1945-Exploratory drilling in Tunisia, Algeria, Nigeria, Trinidad and offshore in British Borneo; Production from the Iraq Petroleum Company.
Royal Dutch shortens its corporate title to "Shell".

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Shell discovers oil in the Sahara.
Joint Shell/Esso exploration company called N.V. Nederlandse Aardolie Maatschappij (NAM) discovers gas fields in Groningen in the Netherlands.
Omani government claims 25% interest Petroleum Development Oman.
Omani government raises its interest in Petroleum Development Oman to 60%  Shell acquires Belridge Oil.
Shell acquires Belridge Oil.
Shell buys minority interest (30%) in Shell Oil US.
Shell Oil Co., Texaco Inc. and Saudi Aramco initiate joint venture combining their eastern U.S. refining and marketing assets under the name.
Occidental and Royal Dutch/Shell, Anglo-Dutch oil group complete a $1bn global asset swap.
Robert Pew founds Sun Oil Company.
New Jersey Oil and Gas incorporated.
Sun buys Sunray (DX).
Sun buys Sunray (DX)  Sun Oil Company reorganized and renamed Sun Company Incorporated.
Joe Cullinan founds Texas Fuel Company.
Joe Cullinan and Arnold Schlaet found The Texas Oil Company in Beaumont, Texas.
Texas Oil Company registers the trademark name, "Texaco".
Texas Oil Company purchases half interest in Bahrain Petroleum and California-Arabian Standard Oil Company (Calarabian) from Socal.
Texas Oil Company joins with Standard Oil of California (later Chevron), to found the Arab-American Oil Company.
California-Texas company, Caltex, founded as a joint venture between Socal and Texas Oil Company as outlet for future oil production in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia.

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Texas Oil Company acquires Regent Oil, a British company.
Texas Oil Company purchases the Paragon group of companies.
Texas Oil Company adopts the name Texaco for all of its businesses.
Texaco acquires White Fuel Corporation.
Purchases Superior Oil Company Venezuela.
Texaco acquires Getty Oil Company.
Texaco Forms Star Enterprise, a 50/50 joint venture with Saudi Refining Inc., to refine, distribute and market Texaco-branded products.
Texaco and Norsk Hydro formed a joint venture, Hydro Texaco, to market petroleum products throughout Scandinavia.
Texaco acquires Monterey Resources, a California based independent oil and gas producer.
Texaco and Shell Oil form downstream alliance in the Western U.S.
Texaco and Shell Oil form downstream alliance in the Western U.S.
Union Oil formed in California by merger of Hardison & Stewart Oil Company, the Sespe Oil Company, and the Torrey Canyon Oil Company.
Union purchases Pinal-Dome Oil Company.
Shell buys 25% of Union Oil of California.
Shell Union Oil Corporation formed to consolidate Shell interests in the US with those of the Union Oil Company of Delaware.
Union acquires Pure Oil.
Union Oil changes name to Unocal.
Ashland Chemical acquires most of Unocal's chemical distribution business, establishing the IC&S Division.
Burmah Oil founded in Scotland.
Shah of Iran signs concession agreement with William D'arcy.
Burmah Oil signs agreement to supply oil to British Admiralty.
Burmah Oil and D'arcy oil merged into Concession Syndicate.
Oil struck in commercial quantities in Iran.
Anglo- Persian Oil formed and Burmah Oil buys majority (97%) of shares in initial public offering.
British government becomes majority stockholder in Anglo- Persian Oil.
Anglo- Persian Oil purchases British Petroleum from British Government, which in turn had seized the company form Deutsche Bank during W.W.I.
Shah cancels Anglo-Persian concession.
Anglo-Persian wins back Iran concession.

Anglo-Iranian and Gulf Oil Corporation establish Kuwait Oil Company as a 50-50 joint venture to compete for Kuwait concession (which they obtain); Subsequent agreement establishes British control of KOC.
Anglo-Persian renamed Anglo-Iranian Oil Company Ltd.
Anglo-Iranian, Jersey and Socony sign 20-year contract with Iran.
Mossadegh nationalizes Anglo-Iranian assets in Iran and founds National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) to administer nationalized assets.
Anglo-Iranian re-named British Petroleum, previously the name of one of its subsidiaries.
British Petroleum begins commercial development in Abu Dhabi.
British Petroleum begins commercial development in Libya.
British Petroleum signs agreement with the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, which became effective in January 1970.
According to the agreement Standard takes over BP's leases in Alaska; In return, BP acquires 25% of Standard's equity, a stake that would rise to a majority holding in 1978.
BP sells 33% of El Bunduq oilfield to a Japanese consortium in exchange for access to Japanese markets.
BP sells 33% of Abu Dhabi Main Areas Ltd. to Japanese oil company.
British government sells of its stock in BP.
British Petroleum acquires remaining stock of Sohio as well as British company Britoil.
Sohio merged with other BP interests to form BP America.
Kuwait Investment Office holding of BP stock reaches 21.6%.
British government forces reduction in KIO holding to 9.9% of BP stock.
BP announces merger with Amoco, new company will operate under the name BP Amoco p.l.c.
Societe Nationale des Petroles d'Aquitaine (SNPA) incorporated at the initiative of the French government.
French government merges gas and oil interests into Enterprise de Recherches et d'Activities Petrolieres (ERAP), giving ERAP majority ownership of SNPA.
ERAP begins onshore and offshore exploration in Iran.
ERAP is reorganized and increases share of SNPA ownership to 70%.
ERAP changes name to Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, known as Elf Aquitaine Group.
Enrico Mattei founds Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi  as a conglomeration of 36 subsidiaries including AGIP, with government sanction.
Signs 50-50 oil cooperation deal with National Iranian Oil Company.
1970-Founds Agip (Qatar) Ltd,  1980s: Libya gains control of 50% of ENI Libya.
Libya gains control of 50% of ENI Libya.
Enoxy, a joint ENI Occidental petrochemical and mining venture founded.
ENI wins contract to construct pipeline in Iraq.
ENI wins portion of a pipeline contact for Yemen.
ENI transformed into joint stock company traded on Italian and NYSE.
Turkish Petroleum Company founded with 50% ownership by Turkish National Bank, 25% Deutsche Bank, 25% Royal Dutch/Shell.
Turkish Petroleum Company reorganized, with Anglo-Persian holding 50%, Deutsche Bank and Shell each holding 25%
Ottoman Grand Vizier promises Mesopotamian concession to Turkish Petroleum Company, but final concession agreement is not signed.
CFP joins Turkish Petroleum Company.
Turkish Petroleum Company gains oil concession in Iraq.
Gulf joins Turkish Petroleum Company.
Royal Dutch/Shell, Anglo-Persian, CFP, Exxon, Mobil, Atlantic Richfield, Gulf Oil Corporation, Standard Oil of Indiana , and Participations.
Turkish Petroleum changes name to Iraq Petroleum Company.
Mosul Petroleum Company formed to hold northern portion of IPC's Iraq concession.
Basrah Petroleum Company formed to hold southern portion of IPC's Iraq concession.
IPC establishes Abu Dhabi Petroleum Company Ltd. (ADPC) to hold Abu Dhabi concession.
British government seizes IPC shares held by CFP.
Iraq revokes portions of IPC concession and nationalizes these concessions.
Iraq nationalizes remaining IPC concessions.
Iraq nationalizes assets of foreign assets in Basrah Petroleum Company.
Iran nationalizes National Iranian Oil Company.
Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Jersey, Socony, Texaco and Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Iricon Agency.
Oil Services Company of Iran (Osco) formed by NIOC to take over operations of IOP.
National Iranian Oil Company signs deal with ENI for oil production.
Mobil enters joint venture with National Iranian Oil Company.

National Iranian Oil Company signs agreement to import about 200,000 barrels a day of gas oil and kerosene from Bahrain, Qatar and Abu Dhabi refineries ending embargoes established during the Iran-Iraq war.

Anglo-Iranian and Gulf Oil Corporation establish Kuwait Oil Company as a 50-50 joint venture to compete for Kuwait concession (which they obtain); Subsequent agreement establishes British control of KOC.
Sheikh Ahmed grants 75-year concession to KOC.
KOC oil concession extended for additional 17 years.
Kuwait National Petroleum Company established as a shareholder company owned by the government and the private sector.
KNPC commissions Shuaiba Refinery, the world's first all hydrogen refinery.
Kuwaiti government acquires 60 ownership of KOC.
KNPC becomes a fully state-owned company.

Kuwait Petroleum Corporation created, KNPC becomes fully owned by KPC; KNPC takes charge of the three oil refineries; Mina Al-Ahmadi, Mina Abdulla and Shuaiba, in addition to the LPG plant in Mina Al-Ahmadi.
Kuwait Oil Company purchases the Santa Fe International Corp., of California.
King Abdul Aziz Bin Abdul Rahman Al-Saud signs agreement authorizing Standard Oil of California (Socal) to explore for oil in what is now the Eastern Province of the Kingdom.
Saudi government signed a concession agreement with the Standard Oil Company of California, predecessor of today's Chevron.
Commercial oil production begins in Saudi Arabia.
Calarabian a joint venture of Socal and Texaco changes name to Arabian-American Oil Company.
Jersey and Socony-Vacuum join Socal and Texaco in Aramco venture.
Saudi Arabia builds Tapline through northern Saudi Arabia, Syria, Jordan and Lebanon to the Mediterranean.

Saudi Arabian Government begins purchasing Aramco's assets from its shareholders, Socal (later Chevron), Texaco, Exxon and Socony-Vacuum (Mobil)  Aramco initiates work to design, build and operate twin industrial cities at Jubail on the Gulf and Yanbu on the Red Sea.
Aramco initiates work to design, build and operate twin industrial cities at Jubail on the Gulf and Yanbu on the Red Sea.
Saudi Government acquires 100 percent of Aramco's shares, although Aramco partners continue to operate and manage Saudi Arabia's oil fields.

Yanbu Petrochemical Company (YANPET), a joint venture petrochemicals complex at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia plant begins operation; Mobil and Saudi Basic Industries Corporation (SABIC) are 50-50 partners in YANPET.
Royal decree establishes the Saudi Arabian Oil Company  to take over the management and operations of Saudi Arabia's oil and gas fields from Aramco.
Saudi Aramco forms a joint venture with Texaco called Star Enterprise; Under the agreement, a Saudi Aramco subsidiary acquires a 50 percent share in Star's three refineries in the United States.
Saudi Aramco acquires a 35 percent interest in SangYong Oil Refining Company, South Korea's third-largest refiner and leading lubricant manufacturer.

Royal decree merges all of the Kingdom's state-owned refining, product-distribution and marketing operations, as well as the Government's half-interest in three joint-venture refineries into Saudi Aramco.
Saudi Aramco enters joint venture with the Philippine National Oil Company (PNOC) purchasing a 40-percent stake in Petron Corp.
Saudi Aramco acquires a 50 percent interest in Motor Oil Hellas and Avin Oil, the refining and distribution affiliates of Greece's Vardinoyannis.

Shell Oil Co., Texaco Inc. and Saudi Aramco initiate joint venture combining their eastern U.S. refining and marketing assets under the name Motiva Enterprises LLC, paralleling a joint venture launched by Shell and Texaco under the name Equilon Enterprises LLC for their Midwest, Southwest and West Coast downstream assets; Shell to own 35% of Houston-based Motiva, while Texaco and Aramco will each own 32.5%.
Foundation of the French Compagnie Francaise Des Petroles (CFP), which assumes French shares of Turkish Petroleum Company.
Discovery of the first oil field near Kirkuk in Iraq.

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Discovery of the Hassi-Messaoud oil field and Hassi R'Mel gas field, in the Algerian Sahara.
CFP absorbs the OFP (Omnium Francais Des Petroles) group.
French Petroleum Company of Canada founded.
The company is renamed Total Petroleum (North America) later that year.
First listing of CFP shares on the London Stock Exchange.
CFP signs an agreement with Abu Dhabi covering development of the Upper Zakum field and production of butane and propane as well as the condensates associated with the oil produced by ADPC (GASCO).
TOTAL acquires Vickers Petroleum Corp., expanding TOTAL's presence in the United States.
CFP changes company name from CFP to TOTAL CFP.
TOTAL CFP acquires all United States hydrocarbon assets of Lear Petroleum Partners.
TOTAL CFP acquires hydrocarbon assets held by TIPCO in the United States as well as those of Francarep Italia, and divests of all refining assets and most of the Group's marketing interests in Italy.
TOTAL CFP acquires CSX OIL & GAS in the United States.
TOTAL CFP changes company name to TOTAL.
Reduction of the French government's direct share holding in TOTAL from 31.7% to 5.4%.
TOTAL signs agreements for establishing the Yemen gas liquefaction project and a development contract for the Iranian offshore fields Sirri A and E.

Divestment by the French State of a further 4% of TOTAL's capital, reducing the government's stake to 0.97%; TOTAL signs a production-sharing agreement for development of Algeria's Tin Fouye; Tabankort field.
TOTAL announces details of its development plans for Iran's giant South Pars gas field in coordination with the National Iranian Oil Co.
Consortium of Phillips, Ashland, Signal Oil and Gas, J.S.
Aminoil wins Neutral Zone concession from Kuwait.
Aminoil acquired by R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc.  Major Frank Holmes establishes Eastern and General Syndicate.
Major Frank Holmes establishes Eastern and General Syndicate.
Eastern and General Syndicate wins al-Hasa Concession.
Eastern and General Syndicate awarded oil concession in Bahrain.
John D. Rockefeller and Henry Flagler found Standard Oil.
Rockefeller organizes his various oil holdings into the Standard Oil Trust, with headquarters in New York.
Standard Oil founds Natural Gas Trust.
Standard establishes regional affiliate, Republic Oil.
Standard establishes Standard Oil of California.

Standard dissolved under court order, creating Standard Oil of New Jersey (Exxon), Standard Oil of New York (Mobil), Standard Oil  (Chevron), Standard Oil of Ohio (Sohio, arm of BP), Standard Oil of Indiana (Amoco), Continental Oil (Conoco), Atlantic (ARCO)
Standard Oil of Indiana sells Venezuela operation to Jersey.
Pan American and Standard of Indiana merge, new company is called American Oil Company.
Amoco begins joint venture with Iran independent of Iranian Oil Consortium.
Amoco signs agreement with Shah of Iran.
Amoco Egypt Oil Company, Cairo, founded.
Amoco Sharjah Oil Company, Sharjah, U.A.E., in partnership with UEA, produces natural gas and natural gas liquids in Sharjah.
Amoco Oman Oil Company begins oil and gas exploration program.
Atlantic Petroleum Storage Company founded.
Atlantic Petroleum Storage Company establishes Atlantic Refining Company (Atlantic).
Atlantic sold to John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Trust.
Richfield Oil Corporation founded.
Standard Oil Trust dissolved under Sherman Antitrust Act, and Atlantic is spun off as independent company.
Sinclair Oil Corporation, founded by Harry F. Sinclair.
Richfield goes into receivership and Sinclair merges with Rio Grande Oil and Prairie Pipeline and Prairie Oil and Gas Companies.
Richfield Oil Corporation emerges from receivership.
Atlantic begins offshore Gulf Coast production.
Atlantic purchased the Hondo Oil & Gas Company.
Richfield Oil Corporation merges with Atlantic Refining Company, creating Atlantic Richfield Company.
ARCO partners with Exxon for Alaskan North Slope production.
ARCO acquires Sinclair Oil Corporation.
ARCO headquarters moves from New York City to Los Angeles.
ARCO acquires the Anaconda Company.
ARCO divests East Coast marketing and refining operations.
Tricentrol acquired by ARCO.
ARCO completes merger with Houston based Union Texas Petroleum Holding Inc.
ARCO forms anew publicly held company, Lyondell Petrochemical.
ARCO's U.S. oil and gas business restructured and divided into four business units ARCO Permian, ARCO Western Energy, ARCO Long Beach.
Vastar Resources Inc. initiates a public offering of 17 million shares of its common stock.
ARCO signs Production Sharing Contract with Sonatrach, the Algerian state oil company, to undertake major Enhanced Oil Recovery project in.
ARCO and Russia's largest oil company, LUKOIL, sign joint venture agreement to invest in oil and gas projects in Russia and other countries.

ARCO subsidiary (Western Midway Co.) and a unit of Mobil Corporation reaches agreement to exchange oil and gas properties in California's San Joaquin Valley and the Gulf of Mexico; The California properties owned by Western Midway go to Mobil, while Mobil oil and gas properties in the Gulf go to Western Midway.
ARCO sells majority interest in ARCO Chemical Company and divests its coal assets in the U.S.
Ashland Refining Company of Ashland, Ky., founded as a refining arm of Swiss Oil Company of Lexington.
Ashland Purchases Tri-State Refining.
Acquires Cumberland Pipeline Company's eastern Kentucky pipeline network.
Ashland Refining merges with Swiss Oil to form Ashland Oil & Refining Company.
Ashland Oil & Refining Company products first sold under the brand name "Ashland".
Ashland and Allied Oil merge.
Ashland and Aetna Oil merge, Ashland acquires Kentucky retail marketing operation Freedom-Valvoline, including Valvoline Motor Oil brand and also acquires Southern Pipe Line Company.
Frontier Oil Refining of Buffalo, N.Y., and National Refining of Cleveland, Ohio, join Ashland.
Acquisition of R. J. Brown Company of St. Louis.
Ashland acquires United Oil.
Ashland acquires Warren Brothers construction company.
Ashland purchases ADM Chemical Group and forms Ashland.
Ashland forms Ashland Petroleum operating division and Arch Mineral.
Ashland changes name to Ashland Oil, Inc.
Ashland acquires Northwestern Refining of St. Paul, Minn. and the SuperAmerica retail marketing chain.
Exploration and production activities are consolidated into Ashland Exploration.
Construction division is formed, and Ashland Coal is created.
Ashland acquires The Permian Corporation and merges with Scurlock Oil Company.
Ashland Chemical acquires most of Unocal's chemical distribution business, establishing the IC&S Division.
Ashland's Valvoline acquires Zerex.
Ashland changes company's name to Ashland Inc.
Ashland signs agreements with Marathon to combine the refining, marketing and transportation assets of the companies.
Pacific Coast Oil Company established.
Pacific Coast Oil purchased by Standard Oil, but remains separate operation.
Pacific Coast Oil consolidated with other Western US operations of Standard Oil into Standard Oil Company (California).
Dissolution of Standard Oil Trust makes Standard Oil of California (Socal) independent.
Socal merges with Pacific Oil Company.
Socal establishes Bahrain Petroleum Company to hold Bahrain concession.
Bahrain Petroleum strikes oil in Bahrain.
Socal wins Saudi Arabia concession; Socal establishes California-Arabia Standard Oil Company, Casoc, to hold concession for Saudi Arabia.
Socal discoveries oil in Saudi Arabia.
Texaco joins with Standard Oil of California (later Chevron), to found the Arab-American Oil Company.
Texaco purchases half interest in Bahrain Petroleum and California-Arabian Standard Oil Company (Calarabian) from Socal.
California-Texas company, Caltex, founded as a joint venture between Socal and Texaco as outlet for future oil production in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia.

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Socal buys Standard of Kentucky.
Bahraini government acquires 60% interest in BAPCO.
Bahraini government acquires remaining interest in BAPCO.
Socal buys Gulf Corporation and after restructuring changes name to Chevron Corporation.
Chevron undertakes a joint venture with the government of the Republic of Kazakhstan forming a new company named Tengizchevroil.
Pennzoil Company assimilates Chevron.
Continental Oil and Transportation Company founded.
Continental Oil and Transportation Company reincorporated as Continental within the Standard Oil trust.
Continental Oil reincorporated after breakup of Standard Oil Trust.
Marland Oil Company founded.
Continental Oil company merged with portions of Rocky Mountain (a former component of Standard oil) and Marland.
Conoco becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of by E.I.
Conoco reorganized as Continental Group.
Standard Oil of New Jersey formed by Standard Oil Trust.
Standard Oil of New Jersey establishes Anglo-American Oil Co. (predecessor of Esso Petroleum Co.) to market oil in the British Isles.
Standard Oil of New Jersey becomes a holding company for Standard Oil Interests, a subsidiary of Standard Oil.
Standard Oil of New Jersey gains control of Imperial Oil Limited of Canada.
Standard Oil of New Jersey acquires interest in Turkish (now Iraq) Petroleum Co.
Standard Oil of New Jersey  becomes independent with dissolution of Standard Oil Trust.
Humble Oil Company formed.
Jersey acquires majority ownership of Humble Oil.
Anglo-American acquired by Jersey.
Socony-Vacuum and Standard of New Jersey merge their Far East facilities and interests into a 50-50 venture called Standard-Vacuum Oil.
Jersey affiliate, Imperial, strikes oil in Canada.
Anglo-Iranian, Jersey and Socony sign 20-year contract with Iran.
Jersey (30%) and Socony-Vacuum (10%) join Socal (30%) and Texaco (30%) in Aramco venture.
Jersey buys remainder of Humble Oil.
Jersey strikes oil in Libya.
Jersey begins to market gasoline under the brand name Esso.
Jersey purchases Monterey Oil.
Jersey buys Honolulu Oil.
Assets of Stanvac split between Jersey and Socony Mobil.
Jersey changes name to Exxon.
Iraq nationalizes Iraq Petroleum Company, of which Exxon is 12% owner.
Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi, Kuwait and Qatar acquire 25% interest in Exxon's production operations (in country), with right to increase stake.
Exxon buys Colony Oil Shale Project.
Exxon sells Esso Standard Libya to Libyan government.
Exxon ends Colony Oil Shale Project.
Exxon acquires 48% of Hunt Oil Company's production sharing agreement in North Yemen.
Exxon and Mobil announce plans for merger.
Pacific Western Oil Corporation incorporated as a holding company for Edward L. Doherty and family which subsequently came under the control of J. Paul Getty.
1930s: Rocky Mountain division of Pacific Western, a Getty subsidiary, begins oil exploration in Saudi Arabia.
Pacific Western wins Saudi Arabia concession.
Getty's Western Pacific Oil Corporation signs concession for Saudi half of the Neutral Zone with Saudi government.
All of J. Paul Getty's oil holdings organized under Getty Oil.
Getty acquires Tidewater Oil.
Texaco acquires Getty.
Guffey Oil founded.
Gulf Refining Company founded.
William Mellon reorganizes Guffey Oil and Gulf Refining under name of Gulf Oil Corporation.
Gulf Oil Corporation forms Eastern Gulf Oil Company.
Gulf joins Turkish Petroleum Company.
Gulf buys Paragon Refining Company.
Gulf sells its share of Iraq Petroleum Company to Socal.

Anglo-Iranian and Gulf Oil Corporation establish Kuwait Oil Company as a 50-50 joint venture to compete for Kuwait concession (which they obtain); Subsequent agreement establishes British control of KOC.
Acquires Warren Petroleum.
Gulf purchases 10% in Syncrude Canada Limited.
Chevron buys Gulf.
Ohio Oil Company founded.
Ohio Oil Company purchased by J.D.
Marathon headquarters moved to Findlay, Ohio.
Standard Oil Company of Ohio  separated from Rockefeller's "Standard Trust".
Ohio Oil Company renamed the Marathon Oil Company.
Marathon buys Plymouth Oil.
Marathon becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of United States Steel Corporation, which has since become USX Corporation.
USX issues separate shares of common stock to reflect the performance of its two major businesses (steel and oil) and reinstates Marathon's symbol (MRO) on major stock exchanges.
Marathon Oil Company headquarters moved to Houston.

Ashland signs agreements with Marathon to combine the refining, marketing and transportation assets of the companies; Marathon Ashland Petroleum LLC formed Ashland acquires 38 percent of Marathon Ashland Petroleum LLC.
After resigning as a geologist with Phillips Petroleum Co., T. Boone Pickens forms development and production company called Petroleum Exploration.
Altair Oil and Gas is established to conduct oil and gas exploration in Canada.
Petroleum Exploration, Inc., and Altair merge to form Mesa Petroleum Co
Mesa Petroleum Co. shares began trading on the American Stock Exchange.
In hostile takeover, Pickens merges larger Hugoton into Mesa.
Mesa sells holdings in Canada and the North Sea to reduce debt and buy additional Hugoton reserves; Mesa also creates the Mesa Royalty.
Mesa forms Gulf Investors Group (GIG).
Mesa repurchases nearly 90 percent of the GIG units in a $500 million public tender offer.
The Mesa Petroleum Company changes its name to the Mesa Limited Partnership.
Mesa purchases Pioneer Corporation.
MESA partnership acquires gas reserves from Tenneco Inc.
Mesa Limited Partnership changes name to MESA Inc.
The Vacuum Oil Co. incorporated.
Standard Oil Co., headed by John D. Rockefeller, purchases a three-quarter interest in Vacuum.
Rockefeller and four partners organize Standard Oil Company in Ohio.
Rockefeller organizes his various oil holdings into the Standard Oil Trust, with headquarters in New York.
Standard Oil of New York formed.
Standard Oil Company of New York (Socony) founded with dissolution of Standard Oil.
Socony purchases a 45% interest in Magnolia Petroleum Co.
Socony purchases the properties of General Petroleum Corp. of California.
Vacuum acquires the Lubrite Refining Co., a refining and marketing company based in St. Louis.
Socony acquires White Eagle Oil & Refining Co.
Vacuum acquires Wadhams Oil Corp., and the White Star Refining Co.
Socony acquires all the assets of Vacuum Oil Co. and changes its name to Socony-Vacuum Corp.
Socony-Vacuum and Standard of New Jersey merge their Far East facilities and interests into a 50-50 venture called Standard-Vacuum Oil.
Socony-Vacuum Corp. changes its name to Socony-Vacuum Oil Co., Inc.
Anglo-Iranian, Jersey and Socony sign 20-year contract with Iran.
Jersey (30%) and Socony-Vacuum (10%) join Socal (30%) and Texaco (30%) in Aramco venture.
Socony-Vacuum changes name to Socony Mobil Oil Company.

Magnolia Petroleum and General Petroleum merged with other domestic subsidiaries into Socony Mobil Oil Company; Two major operating divisions created within the company: Mobil Oil Co. for the U.S. and Canada, and Mobil International Oil Co. for the rest of the world (except the areas in which Stanvac had interests).
Mobil Chemical Co. formed.
Mobil Petroleum Co. Inc. formed to oversee Socony Mobil's 50% interest in Stanvac.
Assets of Stanvac split between Jersey and Socony Mobil.
Socony Mobil Oil Co. changes name to Mobil Oil Corporation.
Mobil enters joint venture with Iranian Oil Company.
Mobil's 11.875% stake in Iraq Petroleum Company is nationalized.
Mobil increases its share of Aramco from 10% to 15%  Mobil completes acquisition of Marcor, the holding company for Montgomery Ward Department Stores.
Mobil completes acquisition of Marcor, the holding company for Montgomery Ward Department Stores.
Mobil Corporation formed as holding company.
Mobil sells 51% of its Turkish refinery to Turkish Petroleum.
Mobil acquires 100% of Superior Oil.

Yanbu Petrochemical Company (YANPET), a joint venture petrochemicals complex at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia plant begins operation; Mobil and Saudi Basic Industries Corporation (SABIC) are 50-50 partners in YANPET.
The Qatargas project, in which Mobil has a 10% interest, comes on line producing first LNG from Qatar.
Mobil commissions two new plants in Yemen and Syria.
Second Qatargas liquefaction train completed.
Exxon and Mobil announce plans for merger.
Cities Service Company formed.
Occidental Petroleum founded.
Cities Service Company obtains Dhofar province concession in Oman.
Armand Hammer buys Occidental Petroleum.
Cities Service Company begins marketing products under the brand name "CITGO".
Occidental wins oil concession in Libya.
Occidental acquires Cities Service Company.
Occidental reorganized Cities' assets and sells newly formed "CITGO Petroleum Corporation" to Southland Corporation
1980s: Libya nationalizes 51% of Occidental's operation in Libya.
Occidental acquired the Midcon Corporation.
Occidental Petroleum Corp. completes acquisition of Placid Oil Co., which was founded in 1936 by H.L.
Occidental purchases 19% stake in Clark USA.
Occidental and Royal Dutch/Shell, Anglo-Dutch oil group complete a $1bn global asset swap.
Occidental sells Occidental Netherlands Inc. unit to TransCanada Pipelines Ltd.
Occidental sells Occidental Netherlands Inc. unit to TransCanada Pipelines Ltd.  South Penn Oil Company organized as a unit of Standard Oil Company.
Name "Pennzoil" trademarked by Pennsylvania Refining Company, a predecessor to Pennzoil.
Bill Liedtke, John Overby, and George Bush form Zapata Offshore Oil Company.
Pennzoil Company is formed through consolidation of South Penn Oil Company, STETCO Petroleum Corporation and Zapata Offshore Oil Company.
Pennzoil Company acquires United Gas Corporation.
Pennzoil Company assimilates Chevron.
Pennzoil Company signs oil development deal with Qatar.
Pennzoil Company agrees to concession agreement with Egypt for Gulf of Suez.
Pennzoil-Quaker State Company was formed with merger of Pennzoil and Quaker State.

Simultaneous with the Pennzoil-Quaker State merger, the Pennzoil Company's marketing, manufacturing and fast oil change businesses (Pennzoil Products Group) is spun off and renamed the PennzEnergy Company.
Phillips brothers begin oil exploration.
Phillips Petroleum Company founded by Frank Phillips.
Phillips forms the predecessor to what today is GPM Gas Corp.
Phillips Research and Development Group formed.
Phillips' Kenai LNG Plant begins operation.
Phillips successfully fends off hostile take-over attempts.
GPM Gas Corporation formed.
Marcus Samuel starts import export business in London.
Royal Dutch Company launched.
Marcus commissions the first special oil tanker and delivers 4,000 tons of Russian kerosene to Singapore and Bangkok.
Samuel's company begins to operate under the name Shell Transport and Trading Company, Limited.
Shell and Dutch company N.V. Koninklijke Nederlandsche Maatschappij tot Explotatie van Petroleum-bronnen in Nederlandsch-Indie form the Asiatic Petroleum Company.
Royal Dutch and Shell group begins joint marketing campaign under name "British Dutch".

1906-British Dutch Group acquires producing interests in: Romania (1906), Russia (1910), Egypt (1911), Venezuela (1913) and Trinidad (1914)  Royal Dutch/Shell partnership is extended worldwide, with the creation of the Royal Dutch / Shell Group of Companies.
Royal Dutch/Shell partnership is extended worldwide, with the creation of the Royal Dutch / Shell Group of Companies.
Trading in the US starts after the acquisition of the American Gasoline Company, an American marketing company.
Turkish Petroleum Company founded with 50% ownership by Turkish National Bank, 25% Deutsche Bank, 25% Royal Dutch/Shell.
Formation of the Shell Company in California.
Royal Dutch/Shell buys Mexican Eagle.
Shell Union Oil Corporation  formed to consolidate Shell interests in the US with those of the Union Oil Company of Delaware.
Shell, Total, and Partex form the consortium Petroleum Development (Oman and Dhofar) later, Petroleum Development Oman.
1945-Exploratory drilling in Tunisia, Algeria, Nigeria, Trinidad and offshore in British Borneo; Production from the Iraq Petroleum Company.
Royal Dutch shortens its corporate title to "Shell".

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Shell discovers oil in the Sahara.
Joint Shell/Esso exploration company called N.V. Nederlandse Aardolie Maatschappij (NAM) discovers gas fields in Groningen in the Netherlands.
Omani government claims 25% interest Petroleum Development Oman.
Omani government raises its interest in Petroleum Development Oman to 60%  Shell acquires Belridge Oil.
Shell acquires Belridge Oil.
Shell buys minority interest (30%) in Shell Oil US.
Shell Oil Co., Texaco Inc. and Saudi Aramco initiate joint venture combining their eastern U.S. refining and marketing assets under the name.
Occidental and Royal Dutch/Shell, Anglo-Dutch oil group complete a $1bn global asset swap.
Robert Pew founds Sun Oil Company.
New Jersey Oil and Gas incorporated.
Sun buys Sunray (DX).
Sun buys Sunray (DX)  Sun Oil Company reorganized and renamed Sun Company Incorporated.
Joe Cullinan founds Texas Fuel Company.
Joe Cullinan and Arnold Schlaet found The Texas Oil Company in Beaumont, Texas.
Texas Oil Company registers the trademark name, "Texaco".
Texas Oil Company purchases half interest in Bahrain Petroleum and California-Arabian Standard Oil Company (Calarabian) from Socal.
Texas Oil Company joins with Standard Oil of California (later Chevron), to found the Arab-American Oil Company.
California-Texas company, Caltex, founded as a joint venture between Socal and Texas Oil Company as outlet for future oil production in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia.

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Texas Oil Company acquires Regent Oil, a British company.
Texas Oil Company purchases the Paragon group of companies.
Texas Oil Company adopts the name Texaco for all of its businesses.
Texaco acquires White Fuel Corporation.
Purchases Superior Oil Company Venezuela.
Texaco acquires Getty Oil Company.
Texaco Forms Star Enterprise, a 50/50 joint venture with Saudi Refining Inc., to refine, distribute and market Texaco-branded products.
Texaco and Norsk Hydro formed a joint venture, Hydro Texaco, to market petroleum products throughout Scandinavia.
Texaco acquires Monterey Resources, a California based independent oil and gas producer.
Texaco and Shell Oil form downstream alliance in the Western U.S.
Texaco and Shell Oil form downstream alliance in the Western U.S.
Union Oil formed in California by merger of Hardison & Stewart Oil Company, the Sespe Oil Company, and the Torrey Canyon Oil Company.
Union purchases Pinal-Dome Oil Company.
Shell buys 25% of Union Oil of California.
Shell Union Oil Corporation formed to consolidate Shell interests in the US with those of the Union Oil Company of Delaware.
Union acquires Pure Oil.
Union Oil changes name to Unocal.
Ashland Chemical acquires most of Unocal's chemical distribution business, establishing the IC&S Division.
Burmah Oil founded in Scotland.
Shah of Iran signs concession agreement with William D'arcy.
Burmah Oil signs agreement to supply oil to British Admiralty.
Burmah Oil and D'arcy oil merged into Concession Syndicate.
Oil struck in commercial quantities in Iran.
Anglo- Persian Oil formed and Burmah Oil buys majority (97%) of shares in initial public offering.
British government becomes majority stockholder in Anglo- Persian Oil.
Anglo- Persian Oil purchases British Petroleum from British Government, which in turn had seized the company form Deutsche Bank during W.W.I.
Shah cancels Anglo-Persian concession.
Anglo-Persian wins back Iran concession.

Anglo-Iranian and Gulf Oil Corporation establish Kuwait Oil Company as a 50-50 joint venture to compete for Kuwait concession (which they obtain); Subsequent agreement establishes British control of KOC.
Anglo-Persian renamed Anglo-Iranian Oil Company Ltd.
Anglo-Iranian, Jersey and Socony sign 20-year contract with Iran.
Mossadegh nationalizes Anglo-Iranian assets in Iran and founds National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) to administer nationalized assets.
Anglo-Iranian re-named British Petroleum, previously the name of one of its subsidiaries.
British Petroleum begins commercial development in Abu Dhabi.
British Petroleum begins commercial development in Libya.
British Petroleum signs agreement with the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, which became effective in January 1970.
According to the agreement Standard takes over BP's leases in Alaska; In return, BP acquires 25% of Standard's equity, a stake that would rise to a majority holding in 1978.
BP sells 33% of El Bunduq oilfield to a Japanese consortium in exchange for access to Japanese markets.
BP sells 33% of Abu Dhabi Main Areas Ltd. to Japanese oil company.
British government sells of its stock in BP.
British Petroleum acquires remaining stock of Sohio as well as British company Britoil.
Sohio merged with other BP interests to form BP America.
Kuwait Investment Office holding of BP stock reaches 21.6%.
British government forces reduction in KIO holding to 9.9% of BP stock.
BP announces merger with Amoco, new company will operate under the name BP Amoco p.l.c.
Societe Nationale des Petroles d'Aquitaine (SNPA) incorporated at the initiative of the French government.
French government merges gas and oil interests into Enterprise de Recherches et d'Activities Petrolieres (ERAP), giving ERAP majority ownership of SNPA.
ERAP begins onshore and offshore exploration in Iran.
ERAP is reorganized and increases share of SNPA ownership to 70%.
ERAP changes name to Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, known as Elf Aquitaine Group.
Enrico Mattei founds Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi  as a conglomeration of 36 subsidiaries including AGIP, with government sanction.
Signs 50-50 oil cooperation deal with National Iranian Oil Company.
1970-Founds Agip (Qatar) Ltd,  1980s: Libya gains control of 50% of ENI Libya.
Libya gains control of 50% of ENI Libya.
Enoxy, a joint ENI Occidental petrochemical and mining venture founded.
ENI wins contract to construct pipeline in Iraq.
ENI wins portion of a pipeline contact for Yemen.
ENI transformed into joint stock company traded on Italian and NYSE.
Turkish Petroleum Company founded with 50% ownership by Turkish National Bank, 25% Deutsche Bank, 25% Royal Dutch/Shell.
Turkish Petroleum Company reorganized, with Anglo-Persian holding 50%, Deutsche Bank and Shell each holding 25%
Ottoman Grand Vizier promises Mesopotamian concession to Turkish Petroleum Company, but final concession agreement is not signed.
CFP joins Turkish Petroleum Company.
Turkish Petroleum Company gains oil concession in Iraq.
Gulf joins Turkish Petroleum Company.
Royal Dutch/Shell, Anglo-Persian, CFP, Exxon, Mobil, Atlantic Richfield, Gulf Oil Corporation, Standard Oil of Indiana , and Participations.
Turkish Petroleum changes name to Iraq Petroleum Company.
Mosul Petroleum Company formed to hold northern portion of IPC's Iraq concession.
Basrah Petroleum Company formed to hold southern portion of IPC's Iraq concession.
IPC establishes Abu Dhabi Petroleum Company Ltd. (ADPC) to hold Abu Dhabi concession.
British government seizes IPC shares held by CFP.
Iraq revokes portions of IPC concession and nationalizes these concessions.
Iraq nationalizes remaining IPC concessions.
Iraq nationalizes assets of foreign assets in Basrah Petroleum Company.
Iran nationalizes National Iranian Oil Company.
Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Jersey, Socony, Texaco and Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Iricon Agency.
Oil Services Company of Iran (Osco) formed by NIOC to take over operations of IOP.
National Iranian Oil Company signs deal with ENI for oil production.
Mobil enters joint venture with National Iranian Oil Company.

National Iranian Oil Company signs agreement to import about 200,000 barrels a day of gas oil and kerosene from Bahrain, Qatar and Abu Dhabi refineries ending embargoes established during the Iran-Iraq war.

Anglo-Iranian and Gulf Oil Corporation establish Kuwait Oil Company as a 50-50 joint venture to compete for Kuwait concession (which they obtain); Subsequent agreement establishes British control of KOC.
Sheikh Ahmed grants 75-year concession to KOC.
KOC oil concession extended for additional 17 years.
Kuwait National Petroleum Company established as a shareholder company owned by the government and the private sector.
KNPC commissions Shuaiba Refinery, the world's first all hydrogen refinery.
Kuwaiti government acquires 60 ownership of KOC.
KNPC becomes a fully state-owned company.

Kuwait Petroleum Corporation created, KNPC becomes fully owned by KPC; KNPC takes charge of the three oil refineries; Mina Al-Ahmadi, Mina Abdulla and Shuaiba, in addition to the LPG plant in Mina Al-Ahmadi.
Kuwait Oil Company purchases the Santa Fe International Corp., of California.
King Abdul Aziz Bin Abdul Rahman Al-Saud signs agreement authorizing Standard Oil of California (Socal) to explore for oil in what is now the Eastern Province of the Kingdom.
Saudi government signed a concession agreement with the Standard Oil Company of California, predecessor of today's Chevron.
Commercial oil production begins in Saudi Arabia.
Calarabian a joint venture of Socal and Texaco changes name to Arabian-American Oil Company.
Jersey and Socony-Vacuum join Socal and Texaco in Aramco venture.
Saudi Arabia builds Tapline through northern Saudi Arabia, Syria, Jordan and Lebanon to the Mediterranean.

Saudi Arabian Government begins purchasing Aramco's assets from its shareholders, Socal (later Chevron), Texaco, Exxon and Socony-Vacuum (Mobil)  Aramco initiates work to design, build and operate twin industrial cities at Jubail on the Gulf and Yanbu on the Red Sea.
Aramco initiates work to design, build and operate twin industrial cities at Jubail on the Gulf and Yanbu on the Red Sea.
Saudi Government acquires 100 percent of Aramco's shares, although Aramco partners continue to operate and manage Saudi Arabia's oil fields.

Yanbu Petrochemical Company (YANPET), a joint venture petrochemicals complex at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia plant begins operation; Mobil and Saudi Basic Industries Corporation (SABIC) are 50-50 partners in YANPET.
Royal decree establishes the Saudi Arabian Oil Company  to take over the management and operations of Saudi Arabia's oil and gas fields from Aramco.
Saudi Aramco forms a joint venture with Texaco called Star Enterprise; Under the agreement, a Saudi Aramco subsidiary acquires a 50 percent share in Star's three refineries in the United States.
Saudi Aramco acquires a 35 percent interest in SangYong Oil Refining Company, South Korea's third-largest refiner and leading lubricant manufacturer.

Royal decree merges all of the Kingdom's state-owned refining, product-distribution and marketing operations, as well as the Government's half-interest in three joint-venture refineries into Saudi Aramco.
Saudi Aramco enters joint venture with the Philippine National Oil Company (PNOC) purchasing a 40-percent stake in Petron Corp.
Saudi Aramco acquires a 50 percent interest in Motor Oil Hellas and Avin Oil, the refining and distribution affiliates of Greece's Vardinoyannis.

Shell Oil Co., Texaco Inc. and Saudi Aramco initiate joint venture combining their eastern U.S. refining and marketing assets under the name Motiva Enterprises LLC, paralleling a joint venture launched by Shell and Texaco under the name Equilon Enterprises LLC for their Midwest, Southwest and West Coast downstream assets; Shell to own 35% of Houston-based Motiva, while Texaco and Aramco will each own 32.5%.
Foundation of the French Compagnie Francaise Des Petroles (CFP), which assumes French shares of Turkish Petroleum Company.
Discovery of the first oil field near Kirkuk in Iraq.

Consortium of oil companies, including British Petroleum, Exxon, Socony, Texas Oil, Socal, Gulf, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and CFP form the Iranian Oil Participants Ltd. (IOP) and negotiate agreement with Iranian government and for oil production in Iran.
Discovery of the Hassi-Messaoud oil field and Hassi R'Mel gas field, in the Algerian Sahara.
CFP absorbs the OFP (Omnium Francais Des Petroles) group.
French Petroleum Company of Canada founded.
The company is renamed Total Petroleum (North America) later that year.
First listing of CFP shares on the London Stock Exchange.
CFP signs an agreement with Abu Dhabi covering development of the Upper Zakum field and production of butane and propane as well as the condensates associated with the oil produced by ADPC (GASCO).
TOTAL acquires Vickers Petroleum Corp., expanding TOTAL's presence in the United States.
CFP changes company name from CFP to TOTAL CFP.
TOTAL CFP acquires all United States hydrocarbon assets of Lear Petroleum Partners.
TOTAL CFP acquires hydrocarbon assets held by TIPCO in the United States as well as those of Francarep Italia, and divests of all refining assets and most of the Group's marketing interests in Italy.
TOTAL CFP acquires CSX OIL & GAS in the United States.
TOTAL CFP changes company name to TOTAL.
Reduction of the French government's direct share holding in TOTAL from 31.7% to 5.4%.
TOTAL signs agreements for establishing the Yemen gas liquefaction project and a development contract for the Iranian offshore fields Sirri A and E.

Divestment by the French State of a further 4% of TOTAL's capital, reducing the government's stake to 0.97%; TOTAL signs a production-sharing agreement for development of Algeria's Tin Fouye; Tabankort field.
TOTAL announces details of its development plans for Iran's giant South Pars gas field in coordination with the National Iranian Oil Co.
Consortium of Phillips, Ashland, Signal Oil and Gas, J.S.
Aminoil wins Neutral Zone concession from Kuwait.
Aminoil acquired by R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc.  Major Frank Holmes establishes Eastern and General Syndicate.
Major Frank Holmes establishes Eastern and General Syndicate.
Eastern and General Syndicate wins al-Hasa Concession.
Eastern and General Syndicate awarded oil concession in Bahrain.
John D. Rockefeller and Henry Flagler found Standard Oil.
Rockefeller organizes his various oil holdings into the Standard Oil Trust, with headquarters in New York.
Standard Oil founds Natural Gas Trust.
Standard establishes regional affiliate, Republic Oil.
Standard establishes Standard Oil of California.

Standard dissolved under court order, creating Standard Oil of New Jersey (Exxon), Standard Oil of New York (Mobil), Standard Oil  (Chevron), Standard Oil of Ohio (Sohio, arm of BP), Standard Oil of Indiana (Amoco), Continental Oil (Conoco), Atlantic (ARCO)
